posts.name: Reza
posts.cooked:
We’re running Kraken X60’s on our MK4i’s for our drive motor and we’ve had this issue that pops up occasionally where one drive motor is inverted.

This only seems to happen on our front left module, which is the first to initialize which led us to think that the old Phoenix V5 bug where TalonFX inverts wouldn’t be set if they were set too early. In order to get around this we added a 1 second delay before initializing each of the modules to try to account for this. Unfortunately, this didn’t seem to fix the problem. At the Magnolia regional during one match the front left module wasn’t inverted properly and it caused us to drive very slowly (since that module was fighting all the other modules and going backwards).

Does anyone have any ideas as to what this problem could be? I haven’t heard of this happening to anyone else so I’m inclined to assume we’re doing something wrong or everyone else has found a workaround lol. Here is our kraken initialization code:

Note that we confirm using Phoenix Tuner X that the motor has not been inverted properly while all the others have by not turning off the robot in matches where this has happened (it’s happened 3x now, we thought we fixed it after Arkansas but I guess not) and checking the motors invert compared to all the others.

(Also thanks to 3937 and 8044 for helping us debug this during the Arkansas regional).

posts.name: Dan Langdon
Tom Winter
posts.cooked:
I suggest searching your code for any refresh calls on that motor (driveMotor.getConfigurator().refresh().

We had a similar problem where one or more of our swerve drives would randomly not invert. After tracking it down, we found that the initial configuration worked just fine (your “apply” code above). However we also had a method that set the motor neutral mode that was getting called later. Our code for setting neutral mode looked like this:

The problem was that the call to “refresh” would sometimes fail.  This caused the subsequent “apply” call to use factory defaults for all settings other than NeutralMode, thus undoing our inverted setting.

Our solution was to never call refresh.  Instead we keep the MotorOutputConfigs instance that we created in the constructor, and just modify that any time we want to make a change to NeutralMode.

So our code to set the neutral mode looks more like this:

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Rezq:

which led us to think that the old Phoenix V5 bug where TalonFX inverts wouldn’t be set if they were set too early

I believe you’re thinking of the problem where the CANCoder wouldn’t return the absolute position if you made the call too early.

The motor inverts will persist across restarts of the motor. I also like to fully reconfigure the motors in code like you are, but the fact that some of the config isn’t applied is an indication that your code must be setting it incorrectly someplace. If the code was only properly configuring it, and it failed, it would simply have no effect and the settings from the last reboot would be applied.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: @tomjwinter Be warned that apply() is a blocking call (with a configurable timeout), so you’ll want to be careful about when you call it. It’s recommended to use the parameters on the control requests to force braking or force coasting instead.

posts.name: Reza
posts.cooked:
This is good to know, thank you!

The problem was that the call to “refresh” would sometimes fail. This caused the subsequent “apply” call to use factory defaults for all settings other than NeutralMode, thus undoing our inverted setting.

I believe we do not use refresh anywhere (we just make our config objects in code exactly as we want them and then just apply that), but i’ll take a look and see if I can find anything. Thanks for that advice as well!

posts.name: Reza
posts.cooked:
I think I may have found it!

We have these two methods over here:

That we call in order to make it easy to move the robot around (sets everything to brake or coast mode). On enable, it calls unlimpModule() by default to make sure the motors are in brake mode however inside .setNeutralMode Phoenix calls refresh and then sets the brake mode config to that refreshed config. The refresh issue you were referring too earlier could then cause the problem that we’re facing.

My only concern with this is, why only the front left module? This has happened ~3 times so far and every time its been on specifically the front left module. The front left module is the one that does do all this on enable (we iterate through our swerve modules array and call unlimpModule() on each) so does that mean the refresh has a higher likelihood of failing on the first one, and not the rest? Does it have to do with the fact that refresh is blocking, maybe allowing the canbus queue to fill up or something like that? idk

Thanks for that suggestion!

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
I haven’t seen it, but I did have a conversation with another mentor that had to switch their swerve code because they were inconsistently seeing inverts not work across their motors.

I think there is likely a race condition bug in the firmware set that will be very difficult to diagnose, but seems like it’s a real problem.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
We check the status flags and redo the operation if they haven’t been set.

Learned that one the hard way from LabVIEW 3 years ago and we’ve carried it forward.  Looking at logs, I know it’s saved us a couple times.

posts.name: Tom Winter
posts.cooked:
I am not sure why only the first motor, but it probably is some sort of timing issue, so I am not too surprised that it is somewhat consistent which one fails.  Ours were pretty random which one failed, but we were also continuously changing things to try to track down or fix the problem.

We also keep track of the apply() result and try again once every second if it fails, but that did not solve our problem - it was changing our coast/brake code that solved our problem.

Also, @gdefender , I do not understand your suggestion about parameters on the control requests.  Which method call should we be using to set swerve/brake to prevent it from being a blocking call?

posts.name: Reza
posts.cooked: He means when you make a control request, there is a parameter in the requests constructor named “ OverrideBrakeDurNeutral” to force brake mode. He recommends using that. TBH i see no problem with doing what you’re doing as long as you’re careful and call it only when necessary when it’s ok to have blocking calls.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
A blocking call means it blocks the thread and waits for the call to complete. Given that everything within a robot loop needs to complete in under 20ms, you need to be careful about blocking calls. I agree with @Rezq that you’re probably OK here, you’re only calling it in enable and disable, not within your periodic loop.

However if your problem is, in fact, that refresh() sometimes fails, a great fix for that would be the use the control request overrides instead. If you’re using Torque Current FOC , you would want to set the neutral mode configuration to brake, and then set OverrideCoastDurNeutral to true on your control request when the robot is enabled. If you’re using Voltage or Duty Cycle it’s the other way around, and you would set OverrideBrakeDurNeutral to true.

posts.name: Tom Winter
posts.cooked: OK, thank you for that clarification. That makes sense.  We only change Brake/Coast when a certain button is pressed while robot is disabled, so for us we will probably leave the blocking calls as is, but will remember this if we ever need to change back/forth while the robot is enabled.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
If the call to setIdleMode() is your issue, you probably want to change the way you handle it. It’s probably not that the call to refresh() is failing , it’s probably timing out, because it is also a blocking call.

You could not reconfigure the motor, and use the control mode overrides. But you also have some options if you do want to reconfigure the motor. Instead of calling setNeutralMode , you could hang onto the MotorOutputConfigs you initially used to configure the motor, like @tomjwinter said. Another option would be to make sure the refresh() is successful before you call apply() :

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked:
gdefender:

You could not reconfigure the motor, and use the control mode overrides.

Do the CoastOut/StaticBreak control modes work when the robot is disabled? Our brief testing earlier this week seemed to indicate no.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
That’s a good question, you’ll have to try it. Just remember that if you do it in a command you will need to override runsWhenDisabled() to return true.

I know you can get the desired behavior (brake on disable, coast on enable) with Torque Current FOC but I’m not sure about Voltage and Duty Cycle.

Torque Current FOC allows you to set the neutral mode to brake and then override it to coast in a control request. When the robot is enabled and sending control requests you can override to coast, and when the robot is disabled it can be brake.

Duty Cycle and Voltage allow you to configure to coast and override to brake in a control request, so unless the control reuqest takes effect when the robot is disabled, it won’t work.

posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked: We are seeing a similar, but not quite an “apply invert config”, issue. Our front left drive motor will ‘randomly’ change it’s positive spinning direction. Running a self test before and after the problem presents itself shows that the motor invert setting has not changed, even though the motor now rotates in the opposite direction.
